chunks.original_latin:
485 Exemplum fidei Sirmio ab Orientalibus
contra Photinum scriptae (ann 351).
chunks.cleaned_english_translation: Example of faith at Sirmium by the Easterners against Photinus, year 351.

We believe in one God, the Father almighty, creator and founder, from whom all fatherhood in heaven and on earth is named. And in His only Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, who was born of the Father before all ages, God from God, light from light, through whom all things were made in heaven and on earth, visible and invisible.

He is the Word, Wisdom, Power, Life, and True Light: who in the last days became incarnate for us, was born of the holy Virgin, was crucified, died, and was buried: who also rose from the dead on the third day, ascended into heaven, sits at the right hand of the Father, and will come at the end of the age to judge the living and the dead, and to reward each according to their works: whose kingdom, persevering without end, remains forever.

For He will be seated at the right hand of the Father, not only in this age but also in the future.

And in the Holy Spirit, the Comforter, whom He promised to the Apostles after He ascended to heaven, to send to teach them and to remind them of everything, through whom also the souls of believers in Him are sincerely sanctified.

However, those who say: The Son is from nothing, or from another substance, and not from God; and that there was a time or age when He was not: the holy and catholic Church knows them as strangers.

Moreover, if anyone says that the Father and the Son are two gods: let them be cursed.

And if anyone, while saying there is one God, does not confess that Christ, the God and Son of God before the ages, obeyed the Father in the creation of all things: let them be cursed.

And if anyone dares to say that the unbegotten God, or a part of Him, was born of Mary: let them be cursed.

And if anyone says that the Son was born of Mary according to foreknowledge or predestination, and not born of the Father before the ages, and that all things were made through Him: let them be cursed.

If anyone says that the substance of God expands and contracts: let them be cursed.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If anyone says that the extended substance of God makes the Son, or refers to the breadth of His substance as the Son, let them be cursed.

If anyone says the Word of God is the implanted or pronounced Son, let them be cursed.

If anyone says that God and man born of Mary means the unbegotten God, let them be cursed.

If anyone, hearing "The Word became flesh" John 1:14, thinks that the Word was changed into flesh or says that it took on flesh through transformation, let them be cursed.

If anyone, hearing that the only Son of God was crucified, says that His divinity suffered corruption, passibility, transformation, diminution, or death, let them be cursed.

If anyone, when hearing "Let us make man" Genesis 1:26, says that it was not the Father speaking to the Son, but God speaking to Himself, let them be cursed.

If anyone says that it was not the Son seen by Abraham in Genesis 18, but the unbegotten God or a part of Him, let them be cursed.

If anyone says that it was not the Son who wrestled with Jacob as a man in Genesis 32:24, but the unbegotten God or a part of Him, let them be cursed.

If anyone, hearing "The Lord rained from the Lord" in Genesis 19:24, does not understand it as referring to the Son and the Father, but says that He rained from Himself, let them be cursed. For the Lord the Son rained from the Lord the Father.

If anyone says that the Lord and the Lord, the Father and the Son, are two gods, let them be cursed. For we do not equalize or compare the Son to the Father, but understand Him as subject. For He did not descend into Sodom without the Father's will; nor did He rain from Himself, but from the Lord, that is, by the authority of the Father; nor does He sit at the right hand by Himself, but hears the Father saying, "Sit at my right hand" (Psalm 109:1).

If anyone says that the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit are one person, let them be cursed.

If anyone says that the Holy Spirit, the Paraclete, is the unbegotten God, let them be cursed.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If anyone, as the Lord taught us, does not call the Paraclete distinct from the Son, for He said, "And the Father will send you another Paraclete, whom I will ask" (John 14:16), let him be accursed.

If anyone says that the Holy Spirit is a part of the Father or the Son, let him be accursed.

If anyone says that the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit are three gods, let him be accursed.

If anyone interprets the words, "I am the first God, and I am the last God, and besides me there is no God" (Isaiah 44:6), as referring to the destruction of idols and those who are not gods, but also to the destruction of the only-begotten God before the ages in a Jewish manner, let him be accursed.

If anyone says that the Son was made by the will of God, like any other creature, let him be accursed.

If anyone says that the Son was born against the will of the Father, let him be accursed. For the Father was not forced or driven by natural necessity to give birth to the Son against His will. Instead, He willed, timelessly and without suffering, to show that the Son was begotten from Himself.

If anyone says that the Son is unbegotten and without beginning, as if speaking of two without beginning, two unbegotten, and two uncreated, making two gods, let him be accursed. For the head, which is the beginning of all things, is the Son; but the head, which is the beginning of Christ, is God. Thus, through the Son, we refer all things to the one who is the beginning of all things without beginning.

And again, confirming the understanding of Christianity, we say that if anyone does not call Christ God, the Son of God existing before the ages and ministering to the Father for the perfection of all things, but says that from the time He was born of Mary, He was named Christ and Son, and began to be God, let him be accursed.

The many deceits of Photinus are refuted.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The Son is neither different from the Father in substance nor in time. The urgency and the occasion required those gathered to provide a more detailed and extensive explanation of the faith through various questions. This necessity arose because many hidden traps were attempting to infiltrate the Catholic faith through the heresy revived by Photinus. Thus, each aspect of the pure and untainted faith could counter each form of heretical and deceptive questioning, ensuring there would be as many affirmations of faith as there were instances of deceitful questioning.

Following that comprehensive and unequivocal explanation of the sacraments, the effort to explain the faith against heretics began here.

However, those who say: The Son is from nothing existing, or from another substance and not from God, and that there was a time or age when he was not: the holy and Catholic Church considers them to be outsiders. What room is there for ambiguity here? Or what is left from the conscience of sincere faith? He is not from nothing existing, which means he has an existing origin. He does not originate from any other substance except that which is of God, ensuring that nothing else can be born in him except all that is of God. Since he exists from nothing, he does not derive his being from elsewhere. He does not differ in time, making the Son timeless with the Father. Therefore, all things between the unbegotten Father and the only begotten Son are inseparable. Time does not distinguish them in any essence, because of the very same indifference of the one existing Father, from whom the birth is taken. If anyone says that the Father and the Son are two gods: let him be anathema. And if anyone, while saying there is one God, does not confess that Christ, the Son of God, existed before the ages and was obedient to the Father in the creation of all things: let him be anathema.

Just as they are one in name of essence, so they are one in kind of essence. The religious profession of this very name provides us with complete understanding of these matters.

nec substantia differt nec tempore.---Necessitas et

Filius, vel de altera substantia et non ex Deo; et
quod erat tempus vel saeculum quando non erat:
alienos scit sancta et catholica Ecclesia. 40. Quis hic ambiguitatis locus? aut quid ex sincerae
fidei conscientia reliquum est? Non est de non
exstantibus: ut ei exstans origo sit. Non est exstans ei
 ad originem substantia aliqua alia, nisi sola quae Dei
est: ut in eo nihil aliud natum esse possit, quam
omne  quod Dei sit; quia non ex nihilo exstans,
aliunde non subsistit. Non differt in tempore: ut cum
Patre sit intemporalis et Filius. Inseparabilia itaque
inter innascibilem Patrem et unigenitum Filium
cuncta sunt, quos in tempore pares ipsa illa unius

dicit deos: anathema sit. III. Et si quis unum dicens Deum, Christum autem
Deum ante saecula filium Dei obsecutum Patri in

illa nominis religiosa professio tribuit.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Since it is condemned to call the Father and the Son two gods, and it is also anathema to deny that the Son is God: the belief in different substances between the two is excluded when proclaiming two gods. For there is no other essence besides that of God the Father, from which the Son of God, an eternal God, is born.

Since we must necessarily confess God the Father, and proclaim absolutely that Christ is the Son of God and God, and since the confession of two gods is irreligious: they cannot, according to the indifference of nature and the indistinguishable name, be anything but one in essence, whose name of essence cannot be anything but one.

If anyone dares to say that the unbegotten God, or a part of Him, was born of Mary: let him be anathema.

The Son and the Father are not one person. Against those who assert that the Son did not exist before Mary except through predestination.

So that the name of the supposed essence in the Father and the Son, due to their dissimilar nature, would not provide an occasion for heretics to preach that the unbegotten God, or a part of Him, was born of Mary; a salvific definition of this pronouncement was made, so that whoever confesses this would be anathema.

For the religious unity of the name, constituted from the essence of an indifferent nature, does not take away the person of the begotten essence, so that the substance of the one and only God is understood through the union of the name: since the name of the essence of both, that is, one God, is proclaimed due to the indistinguishable substance of their undivided nature.

If anyone says that the Son exists according to foreknowledge and predestination before Mary, and not that He was born of the Father before all ages and that all things were made through Him: let him be anathema.
chunks.original_latin:

damnatione sit, Patrem et Filium duos deos dicere;
et rursum anathema sit, Filium Deum negare: substantiae

de Maria natum esse audet dicere: anathema sit. 42. Filii et Patris non una persona. Contra eos qui
asserunt Filium ante Mariam non esse nisi per praedestinationem. ---Ne quod nuncupatae essentiae in Patre
et Filio, per indissimilem naturam, nomen unum
 est, occasionem haereticis praestaret, ut innascibilem
Deum, vel partem ejus, nasci de Maria praedicarent;

esset hoc confitens. Non enim religiosa unitas
nominis, ex indifferentis naturae essentia constituta,
personam genitae ademit essentiae, ut  unici ac singularis
Dei substantia per unionem nominis intelligatur:
cum utriusque essentiae nomen unum, id est,
Deus unus, ob indiscretae in utroque naturae indissimilem

ante Mariam dicit Filium esse, non ante
saecula ex Patre natum apud Deum esse, et per eum

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
God, the Son of God for all of us, they claim, existed before being born in the body, but not by the essence of a subsisting nature; rather, according to foreknowledge and predestination. Through the foreknowledge of the Father, who predestined Him to be born of a virgin, He was announced to us, rather than having existed before the ages in the substance of divine nature. Everything He spoke through the prophets about the mysteries of His incarnation and passion was said by the Father about Him according to foreknowledge. Therefore, this doctrine is condemned: that the only begotten Son of God, known to us, was born of the Father before the ages and created the ages along with all creatures, rather than being predestined to be born.

If anyone says that the substance of God can expand and contract, let them be cursed. Expansion and contraction do not apply to God, nor is the Son an expansion of the divine substance. Expansion and contraction are physical processes, but God, who is spirit and breathes where He wills, does not expand or contract through a change of substance. Remaining free from the necessity of physical nature, He accomplishes what He wills, when He wills, and where He wills. Therefore, it is blasphemous to attribute a change of substance to the freedom of such great power.

If anyone says that the Son makes the substance of God expand or calls the Son an expansion of His substance, let them be cursed. The previous statement, even though it aimed to teach the immutability of God, prepared itself for the following heresy. Some have dared to extend the innascible God through the expansion of substance to the holy Virgin, so that the extension of breadth, taking on a human nature, would be called the Son; and that the Son, born before the ages as perfect God, would later be born as man. Therefore, the whole of this is condemned by the Catholic faith, in which the Father is said to be changeable, and the Son is denied to have been born.

 Deum usque ad sanctam Virginem substantiae dilatatione

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If anyone says that the Son of God is merely a spoken or written word, let them be cursed. Heretics proclaim the Son of God as just a word. The Son from Mary is both God and man.

Heretics, as much as they can, diminish the Son of God, acknowledging Him merely as a spoken word from the mouth of the speaker, and as an immaterial sound of an unsubstantial voice. As if the Son is to God the Father, as a word is to us through our natural ability to speak, which produces every word as a voice. Therefore, all this deceit is condemned, which claims that the Word of God, which was in the beginning with God, is merely a spoken or written word.

If anyone says that the Son from Mary is only a man, let them be cursed. We do not proclaim the Son of God from Mary unless we proclaim Him as both man and God. But to prevent this proclamation of both God and man from becoming an occasion for deceit, it is immediately stated.

If anyone says that God and man born from Mary understands God as unbegotten, let them be cursed.

The Son is distinguished from the Father only by birth. Taking on flesh, He was not changed.

The substance, name, and power are preserved. For if anyone says that the Son of God from Mary is merely a man without God, they are condemned. And the same judgment applies to anyone who says that God, who is in man, is unbegotten. Not that the God who is in man is not God, but that the unbegotten God is denied, distinguishing the Father from the Son not by the name of nature, because there is no difference in substance, but by the authority of being unbegotten alone.

If anyone hears that the Word became flesh and thinks that the Word was transformed into flesh or says that the Word took on flesh by undergoing change, let them be cursed.

The deity did not suffer corruption when the Son of God was crucified. The dignity of divinity is preserved, so that in the fact that the Word became flesh, while the Word became flesh, it did not lose what it was as the Word through the flesh, nor was it transformed into flesh to cease being the Word. But the Word became flesh so that the flesh rather began to be what the Word was.

Deum et hominem praedicamus, fraudis habeat occasionem,

dicens, Deum innascibilem sic intelligit: anathema
sit. 47. Filius sola nativitate a Patre discernitur. Carnem

Through the voice of God the Father, it is clear that He who is born from Himself, with an essence identical to His nature, is indeed God. This is why the Jews refer to their union with God, as they do not recognize the only-begotten God. However, we, while denying the existence of two gods, reject any difference in the natural essence of the Father and the Son. What is not God beside me dispels the false belief in other gods. While confessing one God, we also declare the Son to be God, affirming that there is no difference in substance between them under one name.

If anyone says that the Son was made as one from creation by the will of God, let him be accursed. The Son originates from the substance of God, not like creatures that are made by His will. God's will brought substance to all creatures, but to the Son, He gave nature from His impassible and unbegotten substance through perfect nativity. All things were created according to God's will: but the Son, born from God, retained the same nature as God. His nature did not produce a dissimilar nature; born from the substance of God, He inherited the nature of His origin, not merely the essence of will like creatures.

If anyone says that the Son was born against the will of the Father, let him be accursed. The Father was not forced by unwillingness or driven by natural necessity to beget the Son when He did not want to; rather, He desired, without hesitation and impassibly, to reveal Him as His only-begotten.

However, the Son is not from an unwilling Father. Since it was taught that the Son's existence was not a result of mere will, like everything else, to avoid the notion that His essence depended solely on will and not also on nature, heretics might claim that God the Father was compelled by a natural law to beget the Son unwillingly. But this is not the case with God the Father: in the indescribable and perfect nativity of the Son, neither will alone begot the Son, nor was the essence of natural law altered or compelled by command.

If anyone says the Son is unbegotten and without beginning, implying there are two without beginning, two unbegotten, and two gods, let them be anathema. The unity of God does not allow for an unbegotten Son. To confess an unbegotten Son is impious. The truth has been sought through the counsel and judgments of the bishops, and understanding has been explained through various professions of written faith, extinguishing impious preaching. The infinite and immense God cannot be fully understood or conveyed by brief human expressions. Brief words often deceive both listeners and teachers; summaries can lead to misunderstandings or distortions, lacking complete reasoning. Therefore, the bishops, with their understanding, used many definitions and more abundant words to teach, due to the complexity of natural understanding. They did this to enrich the listeners' understanding with the distinctions of many truths, ensuring nothing dangerous or obscure was spoken about divine matters in this multifaceted resolution of opinions.

Beloved Brothers, do not be surprised that faith has begun to be explained so frequently: this necessity is due to the fury of heresy. The faith given in the first exposition was necessary because at Sirmium, through Hosius, who had forgotten his deeds and words, a new and long-festering doctrine of impiety had emerged. However, I say nothing about him, as it was left to human judgment to remember how he had lived before. Everywhere there are scandals, schisms, and betrayals. As a result, some who had previously written otherwise were compelled to subscribe to a new profession of faith.

I do not criticize the most patient men, the Eastern bishops, who were at least satisfied with the profession of faith after the will of blasphemy. It seems a cause for rejoicing that, amid the heretical obstinacy of so many blaspheming bishops, someone among them is received as repentant.

Hilary's faith concerning the Father and the Son. We indeed confess in the gift of the Holy Spirit always innocently, and we willingly write, not two gods, but one God: nor thereby excluding the Son of God; for He is God from God.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Now, since our faith, as far as I know, has not been in danger with God for 500 years, and I have shown you, as you requested, the faith expressed by the Eastern bishops, I will summarize briefly. chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
But truly, if the Father and the Son are said to be of one substance, meaning they are one and the same under different names, then we do not truly acknowledge the Son by name. If we confess one substance but say that the same unique being is both the Father and the Son, we miss the point.

Moreover, this confusion arises because it might seem that the Father is divided from himself, creating a part that becomes the Son. Heretics, proclaiming one substance, assert this idea, and our pious language can unintentionally support their error. Because this term is vague, it can lead to misunderstanding.

There is a third error: when we say the Father and the Son are of one substance, it can be misunderstood to mean a prior substance that both share equally. This interpretation implies three entities: one substance and two co-heirs of that substance. Just as two heirs share an inheritance, the two could seem like partners of a prior single substance.

So, when we proclaim the one substance of the Father and the Son, it could either mean one being with two names, or a divided substance creating two incomplete beings, or a third prior substance that the two have taken on, splitting one into two.

But where, then, is the concept of birth? How do we understand the Father and the Son if they are seen more as a division or sharing of a prior substance rather than a natural birth?

In these many and serious dangers to faith, we must use precise language. Otherwise, what is meant piously might be interpreted impiously, and a well-meaning statement could become heretical.

A Catholic should not start by saying the one substance of the Father and the Son, nor should they consider this the most important point, as if true faith depends solely on it.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
He confidently asserts one substance, even though he previously said, "The Father is unbegotten; the Son is born, existing from the Father, similar to the Father in power, honor, and nature." He is subject to the Father as his author: he did not consider equality with God something to be grasped, but remained in God's form and was obedient unto death. He is not from nothing, but is born. He is not unbegotten, but coeternal. He is not the Father, but the Son from Him. He is not a part, but whole. He is not the author himself, but the image: the image of God born from God into God. He is not a creature, but is God. Not another God in type of substance, but one God through the essence of identical substance. God is not one person, but one nature: because the born and the begetter have nothing diverse or unlike in them. And after this, by saying the one substance of the Father and the Son, he does not err: but by denying one substance, he sins.

Therefore, let no one think that the one substance is denied by us: whose reason is therefore shown, lest it be denied. Let no one think the one substance should be preached in a short and bare manner: so it may be religiously said to be one substance.

For I do not hear, Christ was born of Mary 502 years ago; unless I also hear, "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God" (John 1:1). I do not hear, Christ was hungry; unless after forty days of fasting I hear, "Man does not live by bread alone" (Matthew 4:4). I do not hear, Christ was thirsty; unless I hear, "Whoever drinks of the water that I shall give him will never thirst" (John 4:13). I do not hear, Christ suffered; unless I hear, "The hour has come for the Son of Man to be glorified" (John 12:23). I do not hear, he died; unless I hear, he rose again.

Let us not bring forth anything isolated from the divine sacraments to the suspicion of listeners and to the occasion of blasphemers. Before the birth of the Son, before subjection, before the similarity of nature is to be preached: so it is not impiously preached that the Father and the Son are of one substance.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
I do not understand why it should be preached above all else as the greatest and most important thing, which cannot be preached piously above all else, and must necessarily be denied impiously afterwards. It can be said piously, and it can be kept silent piously.

It is not, Dearest Brothers, to be denied that the Father and the Son are of one substance, but neither should it be preached irrationally. Let there be one substance from the property of the begotten nature; let it not be from a portion, or from a union, or from a sharing. One substance can be said piously, and kept silent piously.

You have the birth, you have the likeness. Why do we hold the word's meaning suspiciously, without differing in the understanding of the matter? Let us believe, and say that there is one substance; but by the property's nature, not to signify an impious union. Let it be one from likeness, not from solitude.

Perhaps likeness seems to have little propriety in itself. If this is the case, I ask how can I equate one to another except through likeness? Or is it not the same to be similar as to be equal? If I say one, it also has the suspicion of uniqueness: if I say similar, it has the comparison of indistinguishability. Between similar and one, I seek what place equal has: and I ask whether it is rather a matter of likeness or solitude.

There is no equality in dissimilar things, nor is there likeness within one. Or how do similar and equal differ, so that equal is again distinguished from one? Therefore, equals are not dissimilar: and what else can be similar except equal, since there is no equality in dissimilar things?

Likeness of nature signifies perfect equality. What likeness is to Moses, equality is to John.

Therefore, Dearest Brothers, preaching that the Son is similar in all things to the Father, we preach nothing else but equal. Likeness signifies perfect equality: and this must be understood from the holy Scriptures.

We read that Adam lived for 230 years and fathered a son in his own likeness, after his image, and named him Seth Genesis 5:3.

I ask, what kind of likeness and image did Adam produce in Seth? Remove the weaknesses of bodies, the beginning of conception, the pains of childbirth, and all human necessities. I ask whether this likeness in Seth differs by nature from the creator or if it was the essence of another kind, making Seth's essence different from Adam's.

But it is Adam's likeness, even if we deny it, because it is not a dissimilar nature. The likeness of nature in Seth was not of another kind, because Seth was born from Adam. Thus, likeness equates the actual things naturally, through the likeness of an indistinguishable essence.

Therefore, every son, according to natural birth, is the equality of the father because he is also the likeness of nature. Blessed John teaches about the nature of the Father and the Son, as Moses speaks of the likeness of Seth and Adam. This same equality of nature is stated when he says: For this reason, the Jews sought all the more to kill him, because he not only broke the Sabbath but also said that God was his Father, making himself equal to God John 5:18.

Why do we insert sluggish minds, burdened with serious sins, and dull and rash senses against indissoluble teachings, into the doctrines and sayings of such great men, and tire the impious? Through Moses, Seth is the likeness of Adam. Through John, the Son is equal to the Father. We seek a third entity, I don't know what, between the Father and the Son, which nature does not accept. He is like the Father; he is the son of the Father; he was born from him. Only by this can it be piously proclaimed that they are one.

Confessing likeness without equality is refuted. Nor does it escape me, dearest brothers, that some, while confessing likeness, deny equality. But let them speak as they wish and inject the poison of their blasphemy into the ignorant.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
If they say there is a difference between similarity and equality, I ask from where equality is compared. If the Son is similar to the Father in essence, power, glory, and time, how does he not appear equal? This is also established in the previous faith as a condemnation: that it would be anathema to say the Father is of a different essence from himself.

Therefore, if he did not give a nature different or dissimilar to the one he begot impassibly, he could only have given his own. Thus, similarity is a property; property is equality, and equality does not differ. And things that do not differ are one; not by union of person, but by equality of nature.

The same power of the Son and the Father. Although it is understood by common sense and divine authorities that there is no difference between similarity and equality, since according to Moses and John, the Son is both similar to and equal to the Father, let us see whether the Lord taught that he is equal to God when the Jews were angry that he equated himself with God by calling God his Father.

For he says, "The Son can do nothing by himself, but only what he sees the Father doing" John 5:19. He distinguished the author when he said, "The Son can do nothing by himself," indicating obedience when he adds, "but only what he sees the Father doing." So, let's understand what the Council of Nicaea aimed for by confessing "homoousion," meaning "of one substance": certainly not to create a heresy from a mistaken understanding of "homoousion."

They did not mean that the Father and the Son divided one prior substance into their own substances. The faith that was written down religiously at that time is what we now also include in our discussion without irreverence.

We believe in one God, the Father Almighty, maker of all things visible and invisible.

And in one Lord Jesus Christ, the Son of God, born from the Father, the only begotten, that is, from the substance of the Father, God from God, light from light, true God from true God, born not made, of one substance with the Father, which in Greek they call "homoousion," through whom all things were made, both in heaven and on earth, who for our salvation came down, was incarnate, became man, suffered, rose again on the third day, ascended into heaven, and is coming to judge the living and the dead.

And in the Holy Spirit.

Those who say, "There was a time when he was not," and "Before he was born, he was not," and "He was made out of nothing," or "He is from another substance or essence," and believe that God is changeable and alterable: the Catholic Church condemns them.

This most holy synod of religious men does not introduce some prior substance divided into two but asserts the Son is born from the substance of the Father.

Do we deny this? Or do we confess something else?

And after explaining the other points of common faith, it says, "Born not made, of one substance with the Father," which in Greek they call "homoousion."

What is the reason for misunderstanding here? It is proclaimed that the Son is born from the substance of the Father, not made, to avoid interpreting the birth of divinity as an act of creation.

Therefore, "of one substance," not to imply that only one exists or subsists, but to show that he, born from the substance of God, does not subsist from elsewhere, nor does he subsist in any diversity of dissident substance.

What Hilary understands by homoousion. Concerns about homoousion are raised. Homoousion, most holy men, I understand as God from God, not of dissimilar essence, not divided, but born, and a natural generation from the substance of the unbegotten God in the Son, according to the likeness, the only-begotten generation. But you say: The ambiguity of homoousios disturbs me with scandal. Again, listen, I beg, without scandal: and the nakedness of homoousios disturbs me. Many things often deceive that are similar. I fear gold leaf because it might deceive me: and yet what appears is similar to gold. I fear the similarity of milk, lest the milk offered to me is not sheep’s milk: because it might appear similar to cow’s milk. For sheep’s milk to be truly similar to sheep’s milk, it cannot be similar unless it is from a sheep. True similarity is in the truth of nature. However, truth in both natures does not deny homoousion. For this is according to the essence of similarity: if a mass similar to a mass does not deceive in the leaf, if milk that is of the same color is not different in taste. Nothing can be similar to gold, unless it is gold: nothing can be similar to milk, unless it is of its own kind. The color of wine has often deceived me: and yet, by taste, I recognized a liquid of another kind. I have seen meats similar to meats: but later taste revealed the dissimilarity of nature to me. For I fear these similarities that are not from the unity of nature.

For I fear, Brothers, the heresies of the East sprouting up at each moment: and what I say I fear now, I have also read. Indeed, nothing in those things which you, ministers of the assumed delegation, brought to be subscribed at Sirmium by the assent of some Easterners, nothing of suspicion was left: but they had from the beginning not a small amount of offense, which I believe you, most holy men Basil, Eustathius, and Eleusius, have silently abolished so as not to bring any scandal. If what was written was correct, it should not have been silenced. But if it is now being silenced because it was not written correctly, care must be taken that it is not spoken of at some point. Sparing these matters, I say nothing further: yet you and I recognize that all the faith written at Ancyra was not like this. I do not speak of a tale of rumor: I hold the faith of letters, not taken from laypeople, but given by bishops.

I beg you, Brothers, remove suspicion and eliminate the opportunity. To prove the homoousion, let us not disapprove of the homoousion.

Let's remember all the holy and resting priests. What will the Lord think of us if we anathematize them now? What will become of us if we bring the matter to the point where, because they were not bishops, we too have not even begun? We were ordained by them, and we are their successors.

Let us renounce the episcopacy if we have taken its office from anathema. Forgive me, Brothers, for my sorrow: what you dare to do is impious. I cannot bear the statement that the homoousion is within anathema according to religious understanding. The name itself has no crime and does not disturb the sense of religion.

I do not know the homoiousion, nor do I understand it, except from the confession of similar essence. I call God of heaven and earth to witness that even when I had heard neither, I always felt that both should be understood through the homoousion and homoiousion. That is, nothing could be similar to itself according to nature, except what was of the same nature.

Having been regenerated long ago and staying in the episcopacy for a while, I only heard the Nicene faith when I was about to be exiled. But the Gospels and the Apostles have informed me of the understanding of homoousion and homoiousion.

What we desire is pious. Let us not condemn the fathers nor encourage heretics. Lest while we call it heresy, we nourish heresy. Our fathers have interpreted the property of homoousion religiously after the Nicene synod. Books exist, conscience remains. If anything needs to be added to the interpretation, let us consult together.

The best state of faith can be established among us, so that neither well-established things are disturbed, nor poorly understood things are cut off.

I have, dear brothers, disregarded the shame of human conscience. Forgetting my humility, I have written about these profound and hidden matters. Compelled by my love for you, I felt it necessary to share them.

I have spoken what I believe, knowing that I owe this service to the Church's mission. Through these letters, I aim to convey the voice of my episcopate in Christ, following the teachings of the Gospels.

It is your duty to discuss, provide for, and act together, so that you may preserve with a religious conscience the faith you have held inviolably until now, and continue to hold on to it.

Remember my exile in your holy prayers. After sharing this faith, I do not know if it is more joyful to return to you in the Lord Jesus Christ, or safer to die.

May God and our Lord keep you untouched and unharmed until the day of revelation, dear brothers.
